awd_titl_txt: Interfacial and osmolyte-induced modulation of protein folding, assembly and adhesion
awd_abstract_narration:
Proteins are fundamental building blocks of life, serving a multitude of functions in our body, from antibodies protecting us from infection, to enzymes catalyzing biochemical reactions. Protein function is intimately tied to the conformations (or shapes) that proteins can adopt. This project seeks to develop new computational tools to probe how surfaces and solution conditions affect protein structure and function. These simulations will guide the design of a new class of proteins for biomaterial applications, including biologically-inspired wet adhesives and protein scaffolds. Codes developed in the context of this project will be made freely available. The PI and her group are actively engaged in outreach activities, including a chemistry program geared at 5th grade students, the development of hands-on modules related to wet-adhesion that will be presented at the Santa Barbara zoo, and the involvement of underrepresented minority high school students in a summer research program.

The focus of this project is on intrinsically disordered peptides, a class of proteins that can take on a multitude of disparate conformations, adopt transient secondary structures, and carry out multiple functions. With their lack of a native fold, they are also prone to self-assemble into structures ranging from fibrils to coacervates. In this project, the structure, function and assembly of model intrinsically disordered peptides will be probed using a hierarchy of simulations techniques, from ab initio molecular dynamics to coarse-grained models. The project will address three specific aims. The first aim will focus on a molecular understanding of wet adhesion, using the intrinsically disordered mussel-foot protein as a model system. Working closely with leading experimental groups in the field of biological adhesion, the PI will investigate how sequence and surface composition affect adhesion. This research will lay the groundwork for the development of a new class of biologically inspired peptides that can serve as underwater adhesives. In a second aim, the PI will use molecular dynamics simulations and the Kirkwood-Buff theory of solutions to determine the mechanism by which the osmolyte TMAO counteracts the protein denaturing effects of the osmolyte urea. An optimized force field for TMAO/urea interactions will be developed and validated based on experimental measurements, and used to study the effects of mixed osmolytes on the aggregation of intrinsically disordered peptides. In a third aim, the PI will develop novel hybrid kinetic Monte Carlo/Molecular Dynamics algorithms that will be applied to the study of fibril elongation.

This project is jointly funded by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Physics of Living Systems Program in the Division of Physics.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF-funded research project led to new insights into bio-inspired adhesion, new computational methodologies to study liquid-liquid separation, and the development of novel force fields to study the stabilizing effects of osmolytes on proteins.

 

Intellectual Merit

 

Bio-inspired adhesion

 

Using the mussel-foot proteins (MFPs) as model systems, we have designed biologically-inspired adhesive peptides and peptoids. Mussel-foot proteins are intrinsically disordered peptides that are secreted by mussels and are responsible for the adhesive properties of these animals. Using replica exchange molecular dynamics simulations and umbrella sampling simulations, in conjunction with Surface Force Apparatus measurements, we identified three amino acids in the mussel-foot proteins that played critical roles in adhesion: Dopa (a post-translationally modified tyrosine capable of making bidentate hydrogen-bonds with mica and titanium oxide), Glycine (necessary to impart the flexibility needed for adhesion), and Lysine (that provides a charged group that mediates initial contact with the surface). We showed that these three amino acids constituted the smallest alphabet for MFP-inspired adhesion, and we used this insight to create novel adhesive peptides and peptoids for biomaterial applications.

 

Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation

 

Liquid-Liquid Phase separation (LLPS) involves the partitioning of polymers into a polymer-rich and a polymer-depleted phase. This process occurs naturally in the cell, for instance, through the formation of membrane-less organelles, and it can also be induced in the laboratory. In the context of this grant, we have developed and applied analytical methods, Field-Theoretic Simulations (FTS), and Molecular Dynamics simulations to study the LLPS of biopolymers. Using FTS, we generate the first field-theoretic phase diagram for a protein system. We showed that differences in the charge patterning of polypeptides chain can significantly modulate phase behavior, with block-charged sequences showing greater LLPS tendency than sequences with randomly distributed charged species along the chain. We studied the LLPS of number of simple biopolymers, as well as extended our approach to look at the thermodynamic driving forces of LLPS of proteins in both in vitro and in cellular conditions. In particular, we studied the Tau protein, an important agent in stabilizing microtubules in neurons. This protein can form liquid assemblies as well as solid-like fibrils under different conditions. Using FTS simulations, we showed that the polyproline-rich domain of Tau as well as the microtubule binding domain of Tau are capable of undergoing LLPS in the presence of nucleic acids, a result that was subsequently confirmed experimentally in cell assays. Our combined computational and experimental results indicate the droplets formed by Tau clustered around microtubules, suggesting a novel functional role for LLPS in which the process of LLPS concentrates Tau near the microtubule and then allows it to then spread on its surface.

 

Solvation thermodynamics of proteins in mixed-osmolyte solutions:

 

An additional major thrust of our research program centered around understanding the effects of mixed-osmolyte solutions on protein conformation. Osmolytes are small organic molecules that can modulate the stability and function of cellular proteins by altering the chemical environment of the cell. We have developed thermodynamically accurate explicit solvent all-atom models for binary TMAO-water (Shea(m) model), betaine-water (KBB model), and ternary urea-TMAO-water mixtures (Netz(m) model), which reproduce experimental Kirkwood-Buff integrals (KBIs), activity derivatives, and the solution densities. Our force field parameters have been successfully applied to study the folding of TrpCage in mixed osmolyte conditions and to predict TMAO-induced thermal collapse of elastin-like polypeptide (ELP) systems.

 

In addition to studying amine-based osmolytes, we also developed solvation thermodynamics-based all-atom models for another class of protein-stabilizing osmolytes: sugars and polyols. Using an additive construct of the peptide backbone and side chain solvations, we developed new sets of parameters for sucrose and sorbitol based on experimental carbohydrate−backbone and carbohydrate−side chain Kirkwood-Buff integrals. We further developed a novel implicit solvent model based on experimental transfer free energies (MIST - Model with Implicit Solvation Thermodynamics) that allows us to efficiently study both protein folding and assembly. This model successfully captures cold and pressure denaturation, and we successfully extended our parameterization approach to study complex solutions, in particular solutions involving co-solutes.

 

Broader Impacts

 

The biophysical research carried out in the context of this proposal has led to new physical insights that have informed other fields of research, notably material sciences. Educational and outreach activities have enabled outreach activities for 5th grade elementary students, research opportunities for 4 high school students, and have offered mentoring opportunities to undergraduate students at Cal-State Universities seeking to apply to graduate school. The grant has trained 3 postdocs, 2 graduate students, and 3 undergraduate students.
